prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong after deciding their girlfriend should start paying some bills after a single incident of her not paying for takeout. 

First, I need to understand the situation. They live together; the author pays all the bills and rent. The girlfriend only works part-time. The issue arises when the author asks her to pay for a $40 takeout because he forgot his wallet. The author is upset about her reaction, which he perceives as disgusted and put out, and now he's considering making her pay more bills.

Now, the key points here: The author has been paying everything, which might have been an agreement they had. The girlfriend's part-time job might mean her income is limited. The incident was minor, just $40, but the author is taking it as a sign to change the financial arrangement. 

Is the author in the wrong? Well, maybe. If they didn't have a prior agreement about splitting expenses, the author unilaterally changing the arrangement after one incident could be unfair. The girlfriend's reaction might be due to feeling it's a sudden shift without discussion. Also, considering her lower income, making her take on more financial responsibility without considering her capacity could be problematic. The author might be overreacting to a small incident, using it as a pretext to impose a new expectation. 

On the other hand, maybe the author feels that the girlfriend isn't contributing enough. But demanding payment after a single small mistake without prior discussion might be harsh. Healthy relationships require communication, so if the author hasn't talked about splitting costs before, this could be a problem. The author's approach might be more about his own feelings of fairness than the actual incident. 

So, putting this together, the answer is likely A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) because he's unilaterally changing the financial arrangement without considering their prior understanding and the girlfriend's financial situation.
